sentences.text: I upgraded my lenny server today.
I guess the previous update is something like two weeks ago.
Now logcheck started sending mails containing only this perl error:
This email is sent by logcheck.

If you wish to no-longer receive it,
you can either deinstall the logcheck package or modify its
are supported and installed on your system.
are supported and installed on your system.
perl: warning: Falling back to the standard locale ("C").
perl: warning: Falling back to the standard locale ("C").
perl: warning: Please check that your locale settings:
perl: warning: Please check that your locale settings:
Obviously there's something wrong with perl.

But I also consider it a bug that logcheck produces
'half' a result in this manner.
It should really not be doing this.
Locale: LANG=en_US.UTF-8, LC_CTYPE=en_US.UTF-8 (charmap=sh: locale: command not found)
Versions of packages logcheck depends on:

ii  adduser            3.110                 add and remove users and groups
ii  bsd-mailx [mailx]  8.1.2-0.20071201cvs-3 A simple mail user agent
ii  cron               3.0pl1-105            management of regular background p
ii  exim4              4.69-9                metapackage to ease Exim MTA (v4) 
ii  exim4-daemon-light 4.69-9                lightweight Exim MTA (v4) daemon
ii  lockfile-progs     0.1.11-0.1            Programs for locking and unlocking
ii  logtail            1.2.68                Print log file lines that have not
ii  mailx              1:20071201-3          Transitional package for mailx ren
ii  sysklogd [system-l 1.5-5                 System Logging Daemon
ii  logcheck-database             1.2.68     database of system log rules for t
perl: warning: Please check that your locale settings:
are supported and installed on your system.
perl: warning: Falling back to the standard locale ("C").
Can't exec "locale": No such file or directory at /usr/share/perl5/Debconf/Encoding.pm line 16.
Use of uninitialized value $Debconf::Encoding::charmap in scalar chomp at /usr/share/perl5/Debconf/Encoding.pm line 17.

Am Dienstag, den 21.10.2008, 19:11 +0200 schrieb Jan Evert van
Grootheest:
> I upgraded my lenny server today.
I guess the previous update is something like two weeks ago.
> Now logcheck started sending mails containing only this perl error:
> This email is sent by logcheck.

If you wish to no-longer receive it,
> you can either deinstall the logcheck package or modify its
> configuration file (/etc/logcheck/logcheck.conf).
>     are supported and installed on your system.
>     are supported and installed on your system.
> perl: warning: Falling back to the standard locale ("C").
> perl: warning: Falling back to the standard locale ("C").
> perl: warning: Please check that your locale settings:
> perl: warning: Please check that your locale settings:
> Obviously there's something wrong with perl.

But I also consider it a bug that logcheck produces
> 'half' a result in this manner.
It should really not be doing this.
It's not really just wrong with perl but your general locale setup.

I expect that you have
a LANG=en_US.UTF-8 entry in the former but not in the later.

This will
spit out messages like this with every other perl code you are using,
like e.g.

also in upgrade logs, and I expect you haven't filed a
bugreport against apt for that, did you.

Pretty please tell locales to generate the locale you set, that's the
only proper fix for that.

This is not limited to logcheck at all, it
affects your whole system.

If you don't have the locales package installed you shouldn't set
LANG to anything else but the standard locale (C or POSIX), especially
not systemwide.

> Am Dienstag, den 21.10.2008, 19:11 +0200 schrieb Jan Evert van
> Grootheest:
>> I upgraded my lenny server today.
I guess the previous update is something like two weeks ago.
>> Now logcheck started sending mails containing only this perl error:
>> This email is sent by logcheck.

If you wish to no-longer receive it,
>> you can either deinstall the logcheck package or modify its
>> configuration file (/etc/logcheck/logcheck.conf).
>>     are supported and installed on your system.
>>     are supported and installed on your system.
>> perl: warning: Falling back to the standard locale ("C").
>> perl: warning: Falling back to the standard locale ("C").
>> perl: warning: Please check that your locale settings:
>> perl: warning: Please check that your locale settings:
>> Obviously there's something wrong with perl.

But I also consider it a bug that logcheck produces
>> 'half' a result in this manner.
It should really not be doing this.
>  It's not really just wrong with perl but your general locale setup.

I expect that you have
> a LANG=en_US.UTF-8 entry in the former but not in the later.

This will
> spit out messages like this with every other perl code you are using,
> like e.g.

also in upgrade logs, and I expect you haven't filed a
> bugreport against apt for that, did you.

>  Pretty please tell locales to generate the locale you set, that's the
> only proper fix for that.

This is not limited to logcheck at all, it
> affects your whole system.

If you don't have the locales package installed you shouldn't set
> LANG to anything else but the standard locale (C or POSIX), especially
> not systemwide.

And I did that, long time ago, 
through 'dpkg-reconfigure locales'.
And with apt its just a warning, here the output is missing.

It's really 
that the perl warning is the only content of the mail.

* Jan Evert van Grootheest <j.e.van.grootheest@caiway.nl> [2008-10-23 19:42:28 CEST]:
> Gerfried Fuchs wrote:

>> Am Dienstag, den 21.10.2008, 19:11 +0200 schrieb Jan Evert van
>> Grootheest:
>>>     are supported and installed on your system.
>>> perl: warning: Falling back to the standard locale ("C").
>>> perl: warning: Please check that your locale settings:
>>> Obviously there's something wrong with perl.

But I also consider it a bug that logcheck produces
>>> 'half' a result in this manner.
It should really not be doing this.
>>  It's not really just wrong with perl but your general locale setup.

I expect that you have
>> a LANG=en_US.UTF-8 entry in the former but not in the later.

This will
>> spit out messages like this with every other perl code you are using,
>> like e.g.

also in upgrade logs, and I expect you haven't filed a
>> bugreport against apt for that, did you.

And I did that, long time ago,  
> through 'dpkg-reconfigure locales'.
Can you provide them, by chance?

And there is
no /etc/locale, I was talking of /etc/locale.gen, just to be sure.
> And with apt its just a warning, here the output is missing.

It's really  
> that the perl warning is the only content of the mail.
I don't think that the output really is missing.

I rather suspect that
there wouldn't had been any output at all but the locale problem
produced output that logcheck (hopefully understandable) thought would
be relevant to send along.

Did you really receive only messages with the perl warnings and no
single line, at all?
I mean, overall, not just in some of the mails.

So, please offer the informations I've asked for above to be able to
take a closer look, thanks.
In debian, /usr/bin/locale is in the libc6 package.

But, for xen from 
ubuntu, I'm using ubuntus libc6 which does not have it.

If somebody would please close this brown-paper bag bug for this naive 
soul, thanks.

Am Donnerstag, den 23.10.2008, 20:06 +0200 schrieb Jan Evert van
Grootheest:
> In debian, /usr/bin/locale is in the libc6 package.

But, for xen from 
> ubuntu, I'm using ubuntus libc6 which does not have it.

> If somebody would please close this brown-paper bag bug for this naive 
> soul, thanks.
No worries, glad we were able to solve the issue.

title: logcheck fails due to a perl warning
